notes: These are the slides from the orientation meeting.The idea of the orientation meeting is to provide an overview about the  school, to discuss practicability's, and to give a broad overview and introduction in the topic.

The idea of SYMPLE:an online school to learn Groundwater modelingInput through online sessions, recorded lessons, and other educational materialsThe school will follow an example applicationThere is a group project that provides an opportunity to apply what you learn, and to get feedback from the experienced trainers

Cooperation with the iNUX Project- SYMPLE School is developed in close cooperation with the iNUX project.- iNUX is an Erasmus+ cooperation project between four European universities.- Partner universities:   - University of Graz (Austria)   - University of Gothenburg (Sweden)   - UPC BarcelonaTech (Spain)   - Technische Universität Dresden (Germany)- The iNUX project develops open-source educational materials.   - Materials are implemented and used within SYMPLE School.   - Designed for use, reuse, and further development.- Access and contribution:   - iNUX webpage: www.gw-inux.org   - GitHub repository: github.com/gw-inux

Implementation Concept of iNUX in SYMPLE School- iNUX builds on a strong foundation of existing high-quality resources.   - Excellent textbooks, lecture notes, reports, and online documents.   - Example: The Groundwater Project with hundreds of freely available books.- These existing materials form the scientific and educational baseline.- Around this baseline, iNUX develops interactive educational components.   - Interactive Jupyter notebooks.   - Streamlit apps for hands-on exploration.   - Use of real-world data and realistic scenarios.- Additional learning aids complement the interactive materials.   - Integrated assessments.   - Digital questions for self-testing and classroom use.- Overall goal:   - Make learning more efficient and engaging.   - Strengthen applied and practice-oriented understanding.   - Support learning within international cooperation frameworks.- Close cooperation with partners such as the Groundwater Project.

Reminder: Groundwater Project- Reminder on the Groundwater Project- Interactive educational materials are available under the topic:   - Interactive education- Current examples include:   - Introduction to boundary conditions.   - Boundary condition module.   - Pumping test analysis module.- These materials demonstrate applied, interactive learning concepts.- More interactive modules and content will be released soon.

Motivation for the Course- Motivation is based on recent and widely reported news.- Example headline: water resources in Iran are running dry.- Such news appears frequently in the media.- Many reports highlight a strong decline in natural groundwater resources.- These examples underline the relevance and urgency of groundwater-related topics.- They provide real-world context for the course content.

Example: Drought Monitor Germany- The slide shows the German Drought Monitor.- It illustrates soil water content across Germany.- Germany is located in central Europe and is generally considered a humid region.- The right side shows plant-available water as percent of available field capacity.- Even in January, dry areas are already visible.- This indicates a lack of precipitation during winter months.- The drought monitor shows:   - Drought conditions in the topsoil.   - Drought signals in the total soil profile.- This is remarkable, as winter is typically expected to be a wet period.- The example highlights increasing drought risk even in traditionally humid regions.

Recommended Talk: John Cherry on Groundwater- Highly recommended talk by John Cherry.- John Cherry is a leading figure behind the Groundwater Project.- The talk was given at UPC Barcelona.- It provides a strong overview of the current state of groundwater resources.- Focuses on the relationship between groundwater and humanity.- Strongly recommended for deeper context and motivation beyond this course.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I3zqpXxtsHY

Starting Point: Global Water Cycle- The course starts with the global water cycle.- The slide shows two representations:   - Left side: illustrative picture of the water cycle.   - Right side: schematic diagram.- Our focus is on the highlighted subsurface part.- The orange-colored area represents groundwater and aquifers.- The red rectangle marks the specific part addressed in this course.- This defines the system boundary for the topics covered.

Motivation Example: Edwards Aquifer (Texas, USA)- Example used as an initial motivation for the course.- The Edwards Aquifer is a highly productive and important aquifer system.- It supplies drinking water to more than 2 million people.- It is also essential for agriculture and industry.- The map shows the location of the Edwards Aquifer within Texas.- Additional images illustrate major springs connected to the aquifer.- The example highlights the societal relevance of groundwater systems.

Water Balance of the Aquifer System- The slide shows the water balance of the aquifer system.- Main input:   - Groundwater recharge.- Main outflows:   - Domestic and municipal water supply.   - Industrial use.   - Agricultural irrigation.   - Military use.   - Discharge to springs.- All components are reflected in changes of aquifer storage.- The time series shows storage variations over time.- Storage is not constant but fluctuates.- This illustrates the need for active groundwater management.- Highlights the balance between natural recharge and human use.

Role of Groundwater Models for Management- Groundwater models are key tools for groundwater management.- The figure shows input data used for a groundwater model.- Displayed are locations of pumping tests across the aquifer.- Pumping tests provide essential hydraulic parameters:   - Transmissivity.   - Storage properties.- These parameters are required to represent aquifer behavior realistically.- The example illustrates how field data feed directly into modeling and management.

Groundwater–Surface Water Interaction- The map shows surface water features in the study area.- Surface water must be considered in groundwater modeling.- Groundwater and surface water are hydraulically connected.- Rivers, springs, and streams interact with the aquifer.- This interaction influences groundwater levels and fluxes.- Proper characterization is essential for realistic groundwater models.

Recharge Zones of the Aquifer System- The slide shows different groundwater recharge zones.- Recharge is the main input to the aquifer system.- Spatial variability of recharge is highlighted.- Different zones contribute differently to total recharge.- Quantifying recharge is essential for water balance and modeling.- Recharge zonation supports improved groundwater management decisions.

Pumping Rates as Major Outflows- The slide shows groundwater pumping rates.- Pumping represents a major outflow of the aquifer system.- Rates vary spatially and between different users.- Quantification of pumping is essential for the water balance.- Pumping data are a key input for groundwater models.- Critical for assessing sustainability and management options.

Model Results: Hydraulic Head Distribution- The figure shows isocontour lines of hydraulic head.- These contours represent a key result of the groundwater model.- They describe the spatial distribution of groundwater levels.- Head patterns indicate flow directions and gradients.- The calibrated model can be used for further analysis.- Supports evaluation of scenarios and management decisions.

Model Results: Water Budget- The figure shows the simulated water budget from the groundwater model.- Results are derived from the short-term GAM.   - GAM = Groundwater Availability Model.- The water budget summarizes inflows, outflows, and storage changes.- It provides a quantitative basis for interpretation.- These results form the basis for management and decision-making.

Importance of Model Calibration and Understanding- The slide shows the groundwater budget from the recalibrated model.- It is compared with the previous model water budget.- Differences highlight the impact of model calibration.- Calibration can significantly change simulated fluxes and storage.- These changes directly affect management conclusions and decisions.- Therefore, understanding groundwater models is essential:   - How models work.   - How calibration is performed.   - How results must be interpreted.- This provides key motivation for SYMPLE School.

Organization of the Lecture- The lecture format allows plenty of room for live discussion.- The audience is heterogeneous in background and experience.- For some, the course will be:   - A primer or introduction.   - A structured overview.- For others, it may be:   - Deeper learning of new concepts.   - A repetition or refresher of known topics.- Use the materials in the way that best fits your needs.- Additional resources are available:   - E-learning platform materials.   - Interactive documents.   - Embedded assessments and exercises.

Introductory Example: Lusatia Open Pit Mining Region- Another introductory example to set the context.- Example also reflects the professional background of the authors and presenters.- Focus on the Lusatia open pit mining region in eastern Germany.- The region is located between Dresden and Berlin.- It is a well-known area with large-scale mining and groundwater management challenges.- Serves as a practical, real-world reference throughout the course.

Open Pit Mining Region: Active and Recultivated Mines- Closer look at the open pit mining region shown in the illustration.- The slide highlights different mining states.- Active mines:   - Marked in one color.   - Currently still in operation.- Recultivated mines:   - Located in close spatial proximity to active mines.   - Mining operations have finished.   - Remaining pits are flooded and filled with water.- The example shows the coexistence of mining phases within one region.- Important context for groundwater and water management.

Inside the Open Pit Mine- The slide shows the inside of an open pit mine.- Illustrates the scale of mining operations.- Very large technical devices are in operation.- Provides an impression of industrial dimensions.- The figure also gives an overview of the geological setup.- Geological conditions are a key factor for groundwater behavior.

Groundwater Conditions in the Open Pit Mine- The photograph shows an open pit mine in operation.- The blue line at the top indicates the natural groundwater table.- The pit bottom is approximately 17 meters below the groundwater level.- This highlights the large vertical scale of mining activities.- The image provides insight into subsurface conditions.- The underground consists of porous media:   - Sands in the upper layers.   - Brownish soft coal layers below.- These geological conditions strongly control groundwater flow and dewatering.

Assessment Break- Short assessment break at this point.- Purpose is to gauge the background knowledge of the audience.- Helps adapt discussion and depth of the lecture.- If you are viewing the slides only:   - Please visit the interactive app.- The app provides:   - Assessment questions.   - Immediate feedback.- Use this as a self-check, not as an exam.

Open Pit Mining and Dewatering Concept- The scheme is provided by a mining authority or mining company.- It illustrates the general working principle of open pit mining.- Gives an overview of the large spatial dimensions involved.- The blue area represents groundwater.- Groundwater is dewatered before and during mining activities.- Dewatering starts at the top and continues as mining progresses.- This is a long-term and large-scale groundwater intervention.- Strong implications for regional groundwater systems.

Dewatering by Gravity Wells- Dewatering is achieved using gravity wells installed in different layers.- Left side of the slide:   - Shows existing wells around the open pit mine.- Right side of the slide:   - Aerial view of the mining area.   - Points indicate vertical dewatering wells.- A typical open pit mine uses around 500 wells.- Design and operation are complex and large-scale.- Management of dewatering requires numerical groundwater models.

Idealized Groundwater Model Illustration- The slide shows an idealized groundwater model.- It is not an operational or real model.- Used to illustrate the scale and complexity of the system.- Highlights the large spatial dimensions involved.- Shows many different boundary conditions.- Different colors indicate different types of boundaries.- Helps to understand the complexity of real-world groundwater management.

When Simple Models Are Sufficient- Not all questions require complex numerical groundwater models.- In some cases, simplified tools are fully adequate.- The slide shows an example with:   - Two lakes in plan view.   - Remaining aquifer material between the lakes.- The aquifer can be assumed homogeneous.- Lakes act as specified head boundary conditions.- The conceptual model illustrates groundwater flow between the lakes.- Example application:   - An accident at the marked arrow location.   - Leakage of contaminants such as fuel or gasoline into the subsurface.- Simple models can answer immediate questions:   - Flow direction.   - Travel paths.   - First-order risk assessment.- An interactive educational example is available in the SYMPLE25 app.

Access to Live Questions- At this point, live questions are available.- Questions are integrated into the interactive educational tool.- If you are only watching the slides:   - Please visit the SYMPLE25 app.- The app provides:   - The same questions.   - Interactive exploration and feedback.- Use this opportunity to actively engage with the content.

Access via QR Code- The QR code links to the interactive educational tool.- Feel free to explore and investigate on your own.- The activities are guided within the seminar.- Use the tool to deepen understanding at your own pace.

Groundwater Modeling Workflow- Concluding slide summarizing the groundwater modeling workflow.- Starting point:   - Definition of the question and purpose.- Development of a conceptual model.   - Highly simplified representation of the system.- Derivation of the mathematical model.   - Simplification of the general groundwater flow equation.   - One-dimensional flow case.   - Two specified boundary conditions.- From this setup, an analytical solution can be derived.- The analytical solution represents the mathematical model.- A suitable code is then selected to solve the model.- In this example:   - Simple analytical solution.   - Directly implemented in Python.   - Forms the basis of the interactive application shown before.

Next Example: Local Water Supply near Dresden- Introduction of another practical example.- Located south of the Lusatia open pit mining region.- Focus on a local water supply company.- Situated close to Dresden.- Example shifts from regional to more local-scale groundwater management.

Task: Groundwater Exploration for Water Supply- Main task is groundwater exploration.- Goal is to make groundwater accessible for local water supply.- The map shows locations of existing boreholes.- Boreholes provide key subsurface information.- Data include geological and hydrogeological insights.- These data form the basis for subsequent groundwater modeling.- Essential starting point for further analysis and planning.

Surface Water Features in the Study Area- Closer look at surface water conditions.- The slide shows different surface water features:   - Lakes.   - Small drainage channels.   - Larger fishing lakes.- These features are part of the local hydrological system.- Relevant for understanding groundwater–surface water interaction.

Archived Data: Pumping Test Evaluation- Example of information retrieved from archives.- Shows a pumping test evaluation.- Analysis based on:   - Type curve matching.   - Analytical methods.- Provides estimates of aquifer hydraulic properties.- Represents classical groundwater investigation approaches.- Forms an important data source for further modeling.

Recent Hydraulic Test and Modeling Needs- The figure shows a recent hydraulic test.- It is a pumping test with extended monitoring.- Provides additional insights into:   - Well behavior.   - Interaction between groundwater and surface water.   - Influence of internal boundary conditions.- Such complexity is difficult to capture with analytical solutions.- Analytical methods are often not sufficient here.- Numerical groundwater models can represent these interactions.- This is a clear application case for numerical modeling.

Example Result: 3D Groundwater Flow Model- Idealized representation of a final modeling result.- Three-dimensional groundwater flow model.- Shows isocontour bodies of hydraulic head.- Illustrates spatial discretization.- Model grid is visible.- Demonstrates the level of detail achievable with numerical models.

Use of Model Results for Decision-Making- Numerical model results support practical decisions.- Example outputs include:   - Spatial distribution of drawdown.- Allows assessment of impacts on:   - Lakes.   - Forests.   - Drains and surface water bodies.- Model also provides pathlines.- Pathlines indicate well capture zones.- Capture zones form the basis for:   - Defining protection zones.   - Evaluating whether a well can be operated as planned.

Role of Analytical Solutions in Groundwater Modeling- For this application, simpler analytical solutions are also available.- Understanding analytical methods remains highly beneficial.- They support interpretation and validation of numerical models.- This is highlighted in a manuscript by Henk Haitjema.- Published in the journal Groundwater.- The work emphasizes analytical knowledge as a core component  of groundwater modeling education.- Reinforces the importance of combining analytical and numerical approaches.

Interactive Tool: Well Capture Zone Analysis- Link to the interactive tool for well capture zone analysis.- Allows exploration of capture zones around pumping wells.- Users can vary key parameters.- Shows the impact of parameter changes on the solution.- Supports intuitive understanding of flow and protection zones.- Tool is intended for guided and self-directed exploration.

Use of Analytical Tools- The slide illustrates how analytical tools are applied.- Left side:   - Analytical solutions are used to verify numerical models.   - Overall flow patterns from numerical and analytical models are comparable.- This increases confidence in numerical model results.- Right side:   - Analytical solutions allow very fast model applications.- Suitable for:   - Parameter variation.   - Sensitivity analysis.   - Quick scenario testing.- Simple tools enable efficient first-order assessments.- Additional web-based tools exist for:   - Stochastic approaches.   - Capture zone delineation.- These tools complement numerical groundwater models.
